questions.questionText: Which of the following is a correct verbal sentence in te reo Māori?
options: Au kei te haere ki te kura.
Kei te haere au ki te kura.
Haere kei te au ki te kura.
Ki te kura au kei te haere.
questions.correctAnswer: Kei te haere au ki te kura.
questions.correctFeedback: Ka pai! That's correct. In verbal sentences, the verb marker and verb typically come before the subject.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Not quite right. In te reo Māori verbal sentences, the verb marker and verb typically come before the subject.
questions.explanation: The correct structure is: [Verb Marker] + [Verb] + [Subject] + [Object/Location]. In this case "Kei te haere (verb marker + verb) au (subject) ki te kura (location)".

questions.questionText: What does the sentence "He kaiako ia" mean?
questions.correctFeedback: Excellent! "He kaiako ia" is a nominal sentence that means "He/She is a teacher".
questions.incorrectFeedback: That's not correct. "He kaiako ia" is a nominal sentence.

questions.questionText: Arrange the words to form a correct sentence in te reo Māori following VSO order.
questions.correctSentence: Kei te kai a Mere i te āporo
questions.correctFeedback: Ka pai! You've correctly applied the Verb-Subject-Object order in te reo Māori.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Not quite right. Remember that te reo Māori uses Verb-Subject-Object order, so the verb phrase "Kei te kai" comes first, followed by the subject "a Mere", and then the object "i te āporo".

questions.questionText: Identify the subject in this sentence:
questions.instructionText: Click on the part of the sentence that tells us who is performing the action.
questions.note: The subject is the person or thing doing the action in the sentence.
questions.correctFeedback: Tino pai! "a Hemi" is the subject of this sentence. In te reo Māori, the subject typically follows the verb phrase.
questions.incorrectFeedback: That's not right. The subject is "a Hemi" - the person who is performing the action of working.

questions.questionText: What tense does "Kei te" indicate in te reo Māori?
questions.correctFeedback: Tino pai! "Kei te" indicates present continuous tense - actions happening right now.
questions.incorrectFeedback: That's not correct. "Kei te" indicates actions happening in the present (right now).

questions.questionText: Match each verb marker with its correct meaning:
questions.correctFeedback: Excellent work! You understand the different verb markers and their meanings.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Some matches are incorrect. Review the verb markers and their meanings.

questions.questionText: Arrange the words to form a correct sentence in English.
questions.sourceText: Kei te haere au ki te whare pukapuka.
questions.correctSentence: I am going to the library
questions.correctFeedback: Ka pai! That's the correct English translation.
questions.incorrectFeedback: That's not quite right. The correct translation is "I am going to the library".

questions.questionText: Identify the verb phrase in this sentence:
questions.instructionText: Click on the part of the sentence that functions as the verb.
questions.note: The verb phrase indicates the action being performed.
questions.correctFeedback: Excellent! "kōrero" (to speak/talk) is indeed the verb in this sentence.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Not quite. The verb in this sentence is "kōrero", which means "to speak" or "to talk".
